fields.title: CoRoT-2b
fields.description:
CoRoT-2b is the second extrasolar planet detected by the COROT space mission. The planet's transit was discovered in observations taken in May 2007 and the discovery was announced on December 20, 2007.

CoRoT-2b orbits the star GSC 00465-01282. The star is yellowish-white star of spectral type G7V with a mass similar to that of the Sun. It is around 930 light years from Earth in the constellation of Aquila. The star has a close companion star which is a late-K type star.

fields.title: HAT-P-25b
fields.description:
HAT-P-25b was discovered in observations by the HATNet Project. The discovery observations were taken between September 15, 2008 and March 16, 2009 and used the HAT-10 telescope in Arizona and the HAT-9 telescope in Hawaii. The discovery was made public in August 2010.

HAT-P-25b orbits the star HAT-P-25 (also known as GSC 1788-01237). The star is in the constellation of Aries (The Ram) and is a yellowish star of spectral type G5 and a size and mass similar to our Sun.

fields.title: TrES-3b
fields.description:
TrES-3b was discovered by the Trans-atlantic Exoplanet Survey (TrES) network. The discovery observations were taken between May 6, 2006 and August 2, 2006 by two 10-cm telescopes but it was also found in observations taken by the Hungarian Automated Telescope Network in 2005. The orbital period was measured to be just 31 hours making it one of shortest orbital periods known at the time.

TrES-3b orbits the star TrES-3 (also known as GSC 03089-00929). The star is yellowish star of spectral type G with a mass slightly less than the Sun.

It can be found in the constellation of Hercules and is around 10 degrees away from the bright star Vega.

fields.title: GJ-1214 b
fields.description:
Gliese 1214 b was discovered in data taken between June and August 2009. The discovery observations were made by the eight identical 40-cm telescopes that form the MEarth Project and follow up observations were taken with the F. L. Whipple Observatory (FLWO) 1.2-meter telescope. The discovery was announced on 16 December 2009.

The host star is a small star around 42 light years (13 parsecs) away from the Earth. It is red and is classified as an M-dwarf with an apparent magnitude of 14.71. Being so close to the Earth, it has a high proper motion on the sky.

The discovery observations, and later observations with the Hubble Space Telescope show that the planet is a "super-Earth"; it has 6.6 times the mass of Earth and a radius only 2.7 times that of Earth. By measuring the spectrum of the planet during a transit, it has been possible to determine that the atmosphere of the planet consists of a dense, steamy, water-based atmosphere.

fields.title: OGLE-TR-132b
fields.description:
OGLE-TR132b was discovered in the third phase of the OGLE photometric surveys that took place from June - July 2001 and February - May 2002. The discovery observations were made by the 1.3-m Warsaw telescope at the Las Campanas Observatory, Chile (operated by the Carnegie Institution of Washington).

The host star is in the constellation Carina and thought to be around 4900 light years from the Earth. Given the great distance, the star is rather faint at magnitude 15.7. It is a yellow-white star of spectral type F which is slightly hotter and brighter than the Sun. As is often the case when looking in the plane of the Milky Way, it is in a crowded field and was not notable. These properties meant that the planet wasn't seen in the original analysis of the data and was only found following more careful searches. The discovery was announced on June 23 2003.
This planet is challenging because the host star is very faint.

fields.title: HAT-P-8b
fields.description:
HAT-P-8b was discovered in observations by the HATNet Project. The discovery observations were taken between September 29, 2003 and February 1, 2004 as well as in July 2006. The observations were made with the HAT-5, HAT-6, HAT-8 and HAT-9 telescopes based at the Fred Lawrence Whipple Observatory in Arizona and on Mauna Kea, Hawaii. The discovery was made public in December 2008.

HAT-P-8b orbits the star HAT-P-8 (also known as GSC 02757-01152 and 2MASS 22520985+3526495). The star is in the constellation of Pegasus and is approximately 750 light years from Earth. It is a yellow-white star that is over three times more luminous than our Sun.

fields.title: Qatar-1b
fields.description:
Qatar-1b was the first planet discovered by the Alsubai Project exoplanet transit survey. The discovery observations were taken between June and September 2010 using four 400mm f/2.8 camera systems based in New Mexico. The dip in the lightcurve was found by analysis software at the University of St Andrews, Scotland. The discovery was announced in December 2010.

Qatar-1b orbits the star Qatar-1 (also known as 3UC311-087990 and USNO-B1.0 1551-00215396) every 34 hours which, at the time of its discovery, made it one of the shortest-period planets found orbiting a star less massive than the Sun. The star is a metal-rich dwarf star of spectral type K. It can be found in the northern constellation of Draco (The Dragon).

fields.title: WASP-2b
fields.description:
WASP-2b was discovered by the SuperWASP wide-field transit survey. It was initially suggested as a candidate planetary system from observations taken between May and September 2004 by the five SuperWASP cameras based on the island of La Palma in the Atlantic Ocean. It was later confirmed by measurements during August and September 2006 with the SOPHIE spectrograph at the Observatoire de Haute-Provence, France and the 60-cm telescope of the Observatoire François-Xavier Bagnoud at St-Luc in the Swiss Alps. The discovery was announced in November 2006.

WASP-2b orbits the star WASP-2b (also known as USNO-B1.0 0964-0543604 and GSC 00522-01199) which has a spectral type K1V and is less massive than the Sun. The star is 470 lightyears away in the constellation of Delphinus (The Dolphin).

fields.title: WASP 43b
fields.description:
WASP-43b was first flagged as a candidate planet by the WASP-South part of the planet-searching SuperWASPproject between January and May 2009.

Follow-up observations made using the CORALIE spectrographat La Silla Observatory in Chile confirmed its existence in 2011. The follow-up observations also provided information about the planet's physical characteristics and orbit.

WASP-43b is an exoplanet known as a 'Hot Jupiter’; it’s a similar size to Jupiter, but twice the mass. The planet orbits around a young, active, and low-mass K-type star called WASP-43, 284 light years away in the constellation Sextans.

At the time of its discovery, WASP-43b had the second-shortest orbit (or “year”) ever detected at approximately 0.8 days (19.2 hours). In addition, at the time of discovery, WASP-43b orbited closer to its star than any other Hot Jupiter known, likely due to its host star's low mass.
